segment.source: 4703(S) A user right was adjusted.
segment.target: 4703(S) A user right was adjusted.

segment.source: (Windows 10)
segment.target: (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes security event 4703(S) A user right was adjusted.
segment.target: Describes security event 4703(S) A user right was adjusted.

segment.source: 4703(S): A user right was adjusted.
segment.target: 4703(S): A user right was adjusted.

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016
segment.target: Windows Server 2016

segment.source: Event Description:
segment.target: Event Description:

segment.source: This event generates when token privileges were enabled or disabled for a specific account’s token.
segment.target: This event generates when token privileges were enabled or disabled for a specific account’s token.

segment.source: As of Windows 10, event 4703 is also logged by applications or services that dynamically adjust token privileges.
segment.target: As of Windows 10, event 4703 is also logged by applications or services that dynamically adjust token privileges.

segment.source: An example of such an application is System Center Configuration Manager, which makes WMI queries at recurring intervals and quickly generates a large number of 4703 events (with the WMI activity listed as coming from svchost.exe).
segment.target: An example of such an application is System Center Configuration Manager, which makes WMI queries at recurring intervals and quickly generates a large number of 4703 events (with the WMI activity listed as coming from svchost.exe).

segment.source: If you are using an application or system service that makes changes to system privileges through the AdjustPrivilegesToken API, you might need to disable Success auditing for this subcategory (Audit Authorization Policy Change), or work with a very high volume of event 4703.
segment.target: If you are using an application or system service that makes changes to system privileges through the AdjustPrivilegesToken API, you might need to disable Success auditing for this subcategory (Audit Authorization Policy Change), or work with a very high volume of event 4703.

segment.source: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.
segment.target: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.

segment.source: Token privileges provide the ability to take certain system-level actions that you only need to do at particular moments.
segment.target: Token privileges provide the ability to take certain system-level actions that you only need to do at particular moments.

segment.source: For example, anybody can restart a computer, but the operating system doesn’t enable that privilege by default.
segment.target: For example, anybody can restart a computer, but the operating system doesn’t enable that privilege by default.

segment.source: Instead, the privilege is enabled when you click Shutdown.
segment.target: Instead, the privilege is enabled when you click Shutdown.

segment.source: You can check the current state of the user’s token privileges using the whoami /priv command:
segment.target: You can check the current state of the user’s token privileges using the whoami /priv command:

segment.source: Event XML:
segment.target: Event XML:

segment.source: Required Server Roles: None.
segment.target: Required Server Roles: None.

segment.source: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2016, Windows 10.
segment.target: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2016, Windows 10.

segment.source: Event Versions: 0.
segment.target: Event Versions: 0.

segment.source: Field Descriptions:
segment.target: Field Descriptions:

segment.source: Subject:
segment.target: Subject:

segment.source: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that requested the “enable” or “disable” operation for Target Account privileges.
segment.target: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that requested the “enable” or “disable” operation for Target Account privileges.

segment.source: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.
segment.target: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.

segment.source: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.
segment.target: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.

segment.source: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).
segment.target: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).

segment.source: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.
segment.target: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.

segment.source: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.
segment.target: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.

segment.source: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.
segment.target: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.

segment.source: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.
segment.target: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.

segment.source: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.
segment.target: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.

segment.source: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that requested the “enable” or “disable” operation for Target Account privileges.
segment.target: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that requested the “enable” or “disable” operation for Target Account privileges.

segment.source: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.
segment.target: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.

segment.source: Formats vary, and include the following:
segment.target: Formats vary, and include the following:

segment.source: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO
segment.target: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO

segment.source: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local
segment.target: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local

segment.source: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL
segment.target: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL

segment.source: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.
segment.target: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.

segment.source: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.
segment.target: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.

segment.source: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”
segment.target: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”

segment.source: Target Account:
segment.target: Target Account:

segment.source: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account for which privileges were enabled or disabled.
segment.target: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account for which privileges were enabled or disabled.

segment.source: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.
segment.target: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.

segment.source: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.
segment.target: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.

segment.source: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).
segment.target: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).

segment.source: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.
segment.target: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.

segment.source: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.
segment.target: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.

segment.source: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.
segment.target: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.

segment.source: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.
segment.target: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.

segment.source: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.
segment.target: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.

segment.source: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account for which privileges were enabled or disabled.
segment.target: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account for which privileges were enabled or disabled.

segment.source: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.
segment.target: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.

segment.source: Formats vary, and include the following:
segment.target: Formats vary, and include the following:

segment.source: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO
segment.target: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO

segment.source: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local
segment.target: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local

segment.source: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL
segment.target: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL

segment.source: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.
segment.target: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.

segment.source: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.
segment.target: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.

segment.source: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”
segment.target: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”

segment.source: Process Information:
segment.target: Process Information:

segment.source: Process ID Type = Pointer: hexadecimal Process ID of the process that enabled or disabled token privileges.
segment.target: Process ID Type = Pointer: hexadecimal Process ID of the process that enabled or disabled token privileges.

segment.source: Process ID (PID) is a number used by the operating system to uniquely identify an active process.
segment.target: Process ID (PID) is a number used by the operating system to uniquely identify an active process.

segment.source: To see the PID for a specific process you can, for example, use Task Manager (Details tab, PID column):
segment.target: To see the PID for a specific process you can, for example, use Task Manager (Details tab, PID column):

segment.source: If you convert the hexadecimal value to decimal, you can compare it to the values in Task Manager.
segment.target: If you convert the hexadecimal value to decimal, you can compare it to the values in Task Manager.

segment.source: You can also correlate this process ID with a process ID in other events, for example, “4688: A new process has been created” Process InformationNew Process ID.
segment.target: You can also correlate this process ID with a process ID in other events, for example, “4688: A new process has been created” Process InformationNew Process ID.

segment.source: Process Name Type = UnicodeString: full path and the name of the executable for the process.
segment.target: Process Name Type = UnicodeString: full path and the name of the executable for the process.

segment.source: Enabled Privileges Type = UnicodeString: the list of enabled user rights.
segment.target: Enabled Privileges Type = UnicodeString: the list of enabled user rights.

segment.source: This event generates only for user rights, not logon rights.
segment.target: This event generates only for user rights, not logon rights.

segment.source: Here is the list of possible user rights:
segment.target: Here is the list of possible user rights:

segment.source: Privilege Name
segment.target: Privilege Name

segment.source: User Right Group Policy Name
segment.target: User Right Group Policy Name

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: SeAssignPrimaryTokenPrivilege
segment.target: SeAssignPrimaryTokenPrivilege

segment.source: Replace a process-level token
segment.target: Replace a process-level token

segment.source: Required to assign the primary token of a process.
segment.target: Required to assign the primary token of a process.

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can initiate a process to replace the default token associated with a started subprocess.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can initiate a process to replace the default token associated with a started subprocess.

segment.source: SeAuditPrivilege
segment.target: SeAuditPrivilege

segment.source: Generate security audits
segment.target: Generate security audits

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can add entries to the security log.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can add entries to the security log.

segment.source: SeBackupPrivilege
segment.target: SeBackupPrivilege

segment.source: Back up files and directories
segment.target: Back up files and directories

segment.source: - Required to perform backup operations.
segment.target: - Required to perform backup operations.

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can bypass file and directory, registry, and other persistent object permissions for the purposes of backing up the system.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can bypass file and directory, registry, and other persistent object permissions for the purposes of backing up the system.

segment.source: This privilege causes the system to grant all read access control to any file, regardless of the access control list (ACL) specified for the file.
segment.target: This privilege causes the system to grant all read access control to any file, regardless of the access control list (ACL) specified for the file.

segment.source: Any access request other than read is still evaluated with the ACL.
segment.target: Any access request other than read is still evaluated with the ACL.

segment.source: The following access rights are granted if this privilege is held:
segment.target: The following access rights are granted if this privilege is held:

segment.source: READCONTROL
segment.target: READCONTROL

segment.source: ACCESSSYSTEMSECURITY
segment.target: ACCESSSYSTEMSECURITY

segment.source: FILEGENERICREAD
segment.target: FILEGENERICREAD

segment.source: FILETRAVERSE
segment.target: FILETRAVERSE

segment.source: SeChangeNotifyPrivilege
segment.target: SeChangeNotifyPrivilege

segment.source: Bypass traverse checking
segment.target: Bypass traverse checking

segment.source: Required to receive notifications of changes to files or directories.
segment.target: Required to receive notifications of changes to files or directories.

segment.source: This privilege also causes the system to skip all traversal access checks.
segment.target: This privilege also causes the system to skip all traversal access checks.

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can traverse directory trees even though the user may not have permissions on the traversed directory.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can traverse directory trees even though the user may not have permissions on the traversed directory.

segment.source: This privilege does not allow the user to list the contents of a directory, only to traverse directories.
segment.target: This privilege does not allow the user to list the contents of a directory, only to traverse directories.

segment.source: SeCreateGlobalPrivilege
segment.target: SeCreateGlobalPrivilege

segment.source: Create global objects
segment.target: Create global objects

segment.source: Required to create named file mapping objects in the global namespace during Terminal Services sessions.
segment.target: Required to create named file mapping objects in the global namespace during Terminal Services sessions.

segment.source: SeCreatePagefilePrivilege
segment.target: SeCreatePagefilePrivilege

segment.source: Create a pagefile
segment.target: Create a pagefile

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can create and change the size of a pagefile.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can create and change the size of a pagefile.

segment.source: SeCreatePermanentPrivilege
segment.target: SeCreatePermanentPrivilege

segment.source: Create permanent shared objects
segment.target: Create permanent shared objects

segment.source: Required to create a permanent object.
segment.target: Required to create a permanent object.

segment.source: This privilege is useful to kernel-mode components that extend the object namespace.
segment.target: This privilege is useful to kernel-mode components that extend the object namespace.

segment.source: Components that are running in kernel mode already have this privilege inherently; it is not necessary to assign them the privilege.
segment.target: Components that are running in kernel mode already have this privilege inherently; it is not necessary to assign them the privilege.

segment.source: SeCreateSymbolicLinkPrivilege
segment.target: SeCreateSymbolicLinkPrivilege

segment.source: Create symbolic links
segment.target: Create symbolic links

segment.source: Required to create a symbolic link.
segment.target: Required to create a symbolic link.

segment.source: SeCreateTokenPrivilege
segment.target: SeCreateTokenPrivilege

segment.source: Create a token object
segment.target: Create a token object

segment.source: Allows a process to create a token which it can then use to get access to any local resources when the process uses NtCreateToken() or other token-creation APIs.
segment.target: Allows a process to create a token which it can then use to get access to any local resources when the process uses NtCreateToken() or other token-creation APIs.

segment.source: When a process requires this privilege, we recommend using the LocalSystem account (which already includes the privilege), rather than creating a separate user account and assigning this privilege to it.
segment.target: When a process requires this privilege, we recommend using the LocalSystem account (which already includes the privilege), rather than creating a separate user account and assigning this privilege to it.

segment.source: SeDebugPrivilege
segment.target: SeDebugPrivilege

segment.source: Debug programs
segment.target: Debug programs

segment.source: Required to debug and adjust the memory of a process owned by another account.
segment.target: Required to debug and adjust the memory of a process owned by another account.

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can attach a debugger to any process or to the kernel.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can attach a debugger to any process or to the kernel.

segment.source: Developers who are debugging their own applications do not need this user right.
segment.target: Developers who are debugging their own applications do not need this user right.

segment.source: Developers who are debugging new system components need this user right.
segment.target: Developers who are debugging new system components need this user right.

segment.source: This user right provides complete access to sensitive and critical operating system components.
segment.target: This user right provides complete access to sensitive and critical operating system components.

segment.source: SeEnableDelegationPrivilege
segment.target: SeEnableDelegationPrivilege

segment.source: Enable computer and user accounts to be trusted for delegation
segment.target: Enable computer and user accounts to be trusted for delegation

segment.source: Required to mark user and computer accounts as trusted for delegation.
segment.target: Required to mark user and computer accounts as trusted for delegation.

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can set the Trusted for Delegation setting on a user or computer object.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can set the Trusted for Delegation setting on a user or computer object.

segment.source: The user or object that is granted this privilege must have write access to the account control flags on the user or computer object.
segment.target: The user or object that is granted this privilege must have write access to the account control flags on the user or computer object.

segment.source: A server process running on a computer (or under a user context) that is trusted for delegation can access resources on another computer using the delegated credentials of a client, as long as the account of the client does not have the Account cannot be delegated account control flag set.
segment.target: A server process running on a computer (or under a user context) that is trusted for delegation can access resources on another computer using the delegated credentials of a client, as long as the account of the client does not have the Account cannot be delegated account control flag set.

segment.source: SeImpersonatePrivilege
segment.target: SeImpersonatePrivilege

segment.source: Impersonate a client after authentication
segment.target: Impersonate a client after authentication

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can impersonate other accounts.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can impersonate other accounts.

segment.source: SeIncreaseBasePriorityPrivilege
segment.target: SeIncreaseBasePriorityPrivilege

segment.source: Increase scheduling priority
segment.target: Increase scheduling priority

segment.source: Required to increase the base priority of a process.
segment.target: Required to increase the base priority of a process.

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can use a process with Write property access to another process to increase the execution priority assigned to the other process.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can use a process with Write property access to another process to increase the execution priority assigned to the other process.

segment.source: A user with this privilege can change the scheduling priority of a process through the Task Manager user interface.
segment.target: A user with this privilege can change the scheduling priority of a process through the Task Manager user interface.

segment.source: SeIncreaseQuotaPrivilege
segment.target: SeIncreaseQuotaPrivilege

segment.source: Adjust memory quotas for a process
segment.target: Adjust memory quotas for a process

segment.source: Required to increase the quota assigned to a process.
segment.target: Required to increase the quota assigned to a process.

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can change the maximum memory that can be consumed by a process.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can change the maximum memory that can be consumed by a process.

segment.source: SeIncreaseWorkingSetPrivilege
segment.target: SeIncreaseWorkingSetPrivilege

segment.source: Increase a process working set
segment.target: Increase a process working set

segment.source: Required to allocate more memory for applications that run in the context of users.
segment.target: Required to allocate more memory for applications that run in the context of users.

segment.source: SeLoadDriverPrivilege
segment.target: SeLoadDriverPrivilege

segment.source: Load and unload device drivers
segment.target: Load and unload device drivers

segment.source: Required to load or unload a device driver.
segment.target: Required to load or unload a device driver.

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can dynamically load and unload device drivers or other code in to kernel mode.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can dynamically load and unload device drivers or other code in to kernel mode.

segment.source: This user right does not apply to Plug and Play device drivers.
segment.target: This user right does not apply to Plug and Play device drivers.

segment.source: SeLockMemoryPrivilege
segment.target: SeLockMemoryPrivilege

segment.source: Lock pages in memory
segment.target: Lock pages in memory

segment.source: Required to lock physical pages in memory.
segment.target: Required to lock physical pages in memory.

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can use a process to keep data in physical memory, which prevents the system from paging the data to virtual memory on disk.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can use a process to keep data in physical memory, which prevents the system from paging the data to virtual memory on disk.

segment.source: Exercising this privilege could significantly affect system performance by decreasing the amount of available random access memory (RAM).
segment.target: Exercising this privilege could significantly affect system performance by decreasing the amount of available random access memory (RAM).

segment.source: SeMachineAccountPrivilege
segment.target: SeMachineAccountPrivilege

segment.source: Add workstations to domain
segment.target: Add workstations to domain

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can create a computer account.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can create a computer account.

segment.source: This privilege is valid only on domain controllers.
segment.target: This privilege is valid only on domain controllers.

segment.source: SeManageVolumePrivilege
segment.target: SeManageVolumePrivilege

segment.source: Perform volume maintenance tasks
segment.target: Perform volume maintenance tasks

segment.source: Required to run maintenance tasks on a volume, such as remote defragmentation.
segment.target: Required to run maintenance tasks on a volume, such as remote defragmentation.

segment.source: SeProfileSingleProcessPrivilege
segment.target: SeProfileSingleProcessPrivilege

segment.source: Profile single process
segment.target: Profile single process

segment.source: Required to gather profiling information for a single process.
segment.target: Required to gather profiling information for a single process.

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can use performance monitoring tools to monitor the performance of non-system processes.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can use performance monitoring tools to monitor the performance of non-system processes.

segment.source: SeRelabelPrivilege
segment.target: SeRelabelPrivilege

segment.source: Modify an object label
segment.target: Modify an object label

segment.source: Required to modify the mandatory integrity level of an object.
segment.target: Required to modify the mandatory integrity level of an object.

segment.source: SeRemoteShutdownPrivilege
segment.target: SeRemoteShutdownPrivilege

segment.source: Force shutdown from a remote system
segment.target: Force shutdown from a remote system

segment.source: Required to shut down a system using a network request.
segment.target: Required to shut down a system using a network request.

segment.source: SeRestorePrivilege
segment.target: SeRestorePrivilege

segment.source: Restore files and directories
segment.target: Restore files and directories

segment.source: Required to perform restore operations.
segment.target: Required to perform restore operations.

segment.source: This privilege causes the system to grant all write access control to any file, regardless of the ACL specified for the file.
segment.target: This privilege causes the system to grant all write access control to any file, regardless of the ACL specified for the file.

segment.source: Any access request other than write is still evaluated with the ACL.
segment.target: Any access request other than write is still evaluated with the ACL.

segment.source: Additionally, this privilege enables you to set any valid user or group SID as the owner of a file.
segment.target: Additionally, this privilege enables you to set any valid user or group SID as the owner of a file.

segment.source: The following access rights are granted if this privilege is held:
segment.target: The following access rights are granted if this privilege is held:

segment.source: WRITEDAC
segment.target: WRITEDAC

segment.source: WRITEOWNER
segment.target: WRITEOWNER

segment.source: ACCESSSYSTEMSECURITY
segment.target: ACCESSSYSTEMSECURITY

segment.source: FILEGENERICWRITE
segment.target: FILEGENERICWRITE

segment.source: FILEADDFILE
segment.target: FILEADDFILE

segment.source: FILEADDSUBDIRECTORY
segment.target: FILEADDSUBDIRECTORY

segment.source: DELETE
segment.target: DELETE

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can bypass file, directory, registry, and other persistent objects permissions when restoring backed up files and directories and determines which users can set any valid security principal as the owner of an object.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can bypass file, directory, registry, and other persistent objects permissions when restoring backed up files and directories and determines which users can set any valid security principal as the owner of an object.

segment.source: SeSecurityPrivilege
segment.target: SeSecurityPrivilege

segment.source: Manage auditing and security log
segment.target: Manage auditing and security log

segment.source: Required to perform a number of security-related functions, such as controlling and viewing audit events in security event log.
segment.target: Required to perform a number of security-related functions, such as controlling and viewing audit events in security event log.

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can specify object access auditing options for individual resources, such as files, Active Directory objects, and registry keys.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can specify object access auditing options for individual resources, such as files, Active Directory objects, and registry keys.

segment.source: A user with this privilege can also view and clear the security log.
segment.target: A user with this privilege can also view and clear the security log.

segment.source: SeShutdownPrivilege
segment.target: SeShutdownPrivilege

segment.source: Shut down the system
segment.target: Shut down the system

segment.source: Required to shut down a local system.
segment.target: Required to shut down a local system.

segment.source: SeSyncAgentPrivilege
segment.target: SeSyncAgentPrivilege

segment.source: Synchronize directory service data
segment.target: Synchronize directory service data

segment.source: This privilege enables the holder to read all objects and properties in the directory, regardless of the protection on the objects and properties.
segment.target: This privilege enables the holder to read all objects and properties in the directory, regardless of the protection on the objects and properties.

segment.source: By default, it is assigned to the Administrator and LocalSystem accounts on domain controllers.
segment.target: By default, it is assigned to the Administrator and LocalSystem accounts on domain controllers.

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can synchronize all directory service data.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can synchronize all directory service data.

segment.source: This is also known as Active Directory synchronization.
segment.target: This is also known as Active Directory synchronization.

segment.source: SeSystemEnvironmentPrivilege
segment.target: SeSystemEnvironmentPrivilege

segment.source: Modify firmware environment values
segment.target: Modify firmware environment values

segment.source: Required to modify the nonvolatile RAM of systems that use this type of memory to store configuration information.
segment.target: Required to modify the nonvolatile RAM of systems that use this type of memory to store configuration information.

segment.source: SeSystemProfilePrivilege
segment.target: SeSystemProfilePrivilege

segment.source: Profile system performance
segment.target: Profile system performance

segment.source: Required to gather profiling information for the entire system.
segment.target: Required to gather profiling information for the entire system.

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can use performance monitoring tools to monitor the performance of system processes.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can use performance monitoring tools to monitor the performance of system processes.

segment.source: SeSystemtimePrivilege
segment.target: SeSystemtimePrivilege

segment.source: Change the system time
segment.target: Change the system time

segment.source: Required to modify the system time.
segment.target: Required to modify the system time.

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can change the time and date on the internal clock of the computer.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can change the time and date on the internal clock of the computer.

segment.source: Users that are assigned this user right can affect the appearance of event logs.
segment.target: Users that are assigned this user right can affect the appearance of event logs.

segment.source: If the system time is changed, events that are logged will reflect this new time, not the actual time that the events occurred.
segment.target: If the system time is changed, events that are logged will reflect this new time, not the actual time that the events occurred.

segment.source: SeTakeOwnershipPrivilege
segment.target: SeTakeOwnershipPrivilege

segment.source: Take ownership of files or other objects
segment.target: Take ownership of files or other objects

segment.source: Required to take ownership of an object without being granted discretionary access.
segment.target: Required to take ownership of an object without being granted discretionary access.

segment.source: This privilege allows the owner value to be set only to those values that the holder may legitimately assign as the owner of an object.
segment.target: This privilege allows the owner value to be set only to those values that the holder may legitimately assign as the owner of an object.

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can take ownership of any securable object in the system, including Active Directory objects, files and folders, printers, registry keys, processes, and threads.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can take ownership of any securable object in the system, including Active Directory objects, files and folders, printers, registry keys, processes, and threads.

segment.source: SeTcbPrivilege
segment.target: SeTcbPrivilege

segment.source: Act as part of the operating system
segment.target: Act as part of the operating system

segment.source: This privilege identifies its holder as part of the trusted computer base.
segment.target: This privilege identifies its holder as part of the trusted computer base.

segment.source: This user right allows a process to impersonate any user without authentication.
segment.target: This user right allows a process to impersonate any user without authentication.

segment.source: The process can therefore gain access to the same local resources as that user.
segment.target: The process can therefore gain access to the same local resources as that user.

segment.source: SeTimeZonePrivilege
segment.target: SeTimeZonePrivilege

segment.source: Change the time zone
segment.target: Change the time zone

segment.source: Required to adjust the time zone associated with the computer's internal clock.
segment.target: Required to adjust the time zone associated with the computer's internal clock.

segment.source: SeTrustedCredManAccessPrivilege
segment.target: SeTrustedCredManAccessPrivilege

segment.source: Access Credential Manager as a trusted caller
segment.target: Access Credential Manager as a trusted caller

segment.source: Required to access Credential Manager as a trusted caller.
segment.target: Required to access Credential Manager as a trusted caller.

segment.source: SeUndockPrivilege
segment.target: SeUndockPrivilege

segment.source: Remove computer from docking station
segment.target: Remove computer from docking station

segment.source: Required to undock a laptop.
segment.target: Required to undock a laptop.

segment.source: With this privilege, the user can undock a portable computer from its docking station without logging on.
segment.target: With this privilege, the user can undock a portable computer from its docking station without logging on.

segment.source: SeUnsolicitedInputPrivilege
segment.target: SeUnsolicitedInputPrivilege

segment.source: Not applicable
segment.target: Not applicable

segment.source: Required to read unsolicited input from a terminal device.
segment.target: Required to read unsolicited input from a terminal device.

segment.source: Disabled Privileges Type = UnicodeString: the list of disabled user rights.
segment.target: Disabled Privileges Type = UnicodeString: the list of disabled user rights.

segment.source: See possible values in the table above.
segment.target: See possible values in the table above.

segment.source: Security Monitoring Recommendations
segment.target: Security Monitoring Recommendations

segment.source: For 4703(S): A user right was adjusted.
segment.target: For 4703(S): A user right was adjusted.

segment.source: As of Windows 10, event 4703 is generated by applications or services that dynamically adjust token privileges.
segment.target: As of Windows 10, event 4703 is generated by applications or services that dynamically adjust token privileges.

segment.source: An example of such an application is System Center Configuration Manager, which makes WMI queries at recurring intervals and quickly generates a large number of 4703 events (with the WMI activity listed as coming from svchost.exe).
segment.target: An example of such an application is System Center Configuration Manager, which makes WMI queries at recurring intervals and quickly generates a large number of 4703 events (with the WMI activity listed as coming from svchost.exe).

segment.source: If you are using an application or system service that makes changes to system privileges through the AdjustPrivilegesToken API, you might need to disable Success auditing for this subcategory, Audit Authorization Policy Change, or work with a very high volume of event 4703.
segment.target: If you are using an application or system service that makes changes to system privileges through the AdjustPrivilegesToken API, you might need to disable Success auditing for this subcategory, Audit Authorization Policy Change, or work with a very high volume of event 4703.

segment.source: Otherwise, see the recommendations in the following table.
segment.target: Otherwise, see the recommendations in the following table.

segment.source: Type of monitoring required
segment.target: Type of monitoring required

segment.source: Recommendation
segment.target: Recommendation

segment.source: High-value accounts: You might have high-value domain or local accounts for which you need to monitor each action.
segment.target: High-value accounts: You might have high-value domain or local accounts for which you need to monitor each action.

segment.source: Examples of high-value accounts are database administrators, built-in local administrator account, domain administrators, service accounts, domain controller accounts and so on.
segment.target: Examples of high-value accounts are database administrators, built-in local administrator account, domain administrators, service accounts, domain controller accounts and so on.

segment.source: Monitor this event with the “SubjectSecurity ID” that corresponds to the high-value account or accounts.
segment.target: Monitor this event with the “SubjectSecurity ID” that corresponds to the high-value account or accounts.

segment.source: Anomalies or malicious actions: You might have specific requirements for detecting anomalies or monitoring potential malicious actions.
segment.target: Anomalies or malicious actions: You might have specific requirements for detecting anomalies or monitoring potential malicious actions.

segment.source: For example, you might need to monitor for use of an account outside of working hours.
segment.target: For example, you might need to monitor for use of an account outside of working hours.

segment.source: When you monitor for anomalies or malicious actions, use the “SubjectSecurity ID” (with other information) to monitor how or when a particular account is being used.
segment.target: When you monitor for anomalies or malicious actions, use the “SubjectSecurity ID” (with other information) to monitor how or when a particular account is being used.

segment.source: Non-active accounts: You might have non-active, disabled, or guest accounts, or other accounts that should never be used.
segment.target: Non-active accounts: You might have non-active, disabled, or guest accounts, or other accounts that should never be used.

segment.source: Monitor this event with the “SubjectSecurity ID” or “Target AccountSecurity ID” that correspond to the accounts that should never be used.
segment.target: Monitor this event with the “SubjectSecurity ID” or “Target AccountSecurity ID” that correspond to the accounts that should never be used.

segment.source: Account whitelist: You might have a specific whitelist of accounts that are the only ones allowed to perform actions corresponding to particular events.
segment.target: Account whitelist: You might have a specific whitelist of accounts that are the only ones allowed to perform actions corresponding to particular events.

segment.source: If this event corresponds to a “whitelist-only” action, review the “SubjectSecurity ID” for accounts that are outside the whitelist.
segment.target: If this event corresponds to a “whitelist-only” action, review the “SubjectSecurity ID” for accounts that are outside the whitelist.

segment.source: Also check the “Target AccountSecurity ID” and “Enabled Privileges” to see what was enabled.
segment.target: Also check the “Target AccountSecurity ID” and “Enabled Privileges” to see what was enabled.

segment.source: Accounts of different types: You might want to ensure that certain actions are performed only by certain account types, for example, local or domain account, machine or user account, vendor or employee account, and so on.
segment.target: Accounts of different types: You might want to ensure that certain actions are performed only by certain account types, for example, local or domain account, machine or user account, vendor or employee account, and so on.

segment.source: If this event corresponds to an action you want to monitor for certain account types, review the “SubjectSecurity ID” to see whether the account type is as expected.
segment.target: If this event corresponds to an action you want to monitor for certain account types, review the “SubjectSecurity ID” to see whether the account type is as expected.

segment.source: External accounts: You might be monitoring accounts from another domain, or “external” accounts that are not allowed to perform certain actions (represented by certain specific events).
segment.target: External accounts: You might be monitoring accounts from another domain, or “external” accounts that are not allowed to perform certain actions (represented by certain specific events).

segment.source: Monitor this event for the “SubjectAccount Domain” corresponding to accounts from another domain or “external” accounts.
segment.target: Monitor this event for the “SubjectAccount Domain” corresponding to accounts from another domain or “external” accounts.

segment.source: Restricted-use computers or devices: You might have certain computers, machines, or devices on which certain people (accounts) should perform only limited actions, or no actions at all.
segment.target: Restricted-use computers or devices: You might have certain computers, machines, or devices on which certain people (accounts) should perform only limited actions, or no actions at all.

segment.source: Monitor the target Computer: (or other target device) for actions performed by the “SubjectSecurity ID” that you are concerned about.
segment.target: Monitor the target Computer: (or other target device) for actions performed by the “SubjectSecurity ID” that you are concerned about.

segment.source: Also check “Target AccountSecurity ID” to see whether the change in privileges should be made on that computer for that account.
segment.target: Also check “Target AccountSecurity ID” to see whether the change in privileges should be made on that computer for that account.

segment.source: User rights that should be restricted or monitored: You might have a list of user rights that you want to restrict or monitor.
segment.target: User rights that should be restricted or monitored: You might have a list of user rights that you want to restrict or monitor.

segment.source: Monitor this event and compare the “Enabled Privileges” to your list of user rights.
segment.target: Monitor this event and compare the “Enabled Privileges” to your list of user rights.

segment.source: Trigger an alert for user rights that should not be enabled, especially on high-value servers or other computers.
segment.target: Trigger an alert for user rights that should not be enabled, especially on high-value servers or other computers.

segment.source: For example, you might have SeDebugPrivilege on a list of user rights to be restricted.
segment.target: For example, you might have SeDebugPrivilege on a list of user rights to be restricted.

segment.source: Account naming conventions: Your organization might have specific naming conventions for account names.
segment.target: Account naming conventions: Your organization might have specific naming conventions for account names.

segment.source: Monitor “SubjectAccount Name” for names that don’t comply with naming conventions.
segment.target: Monitor “SubjectAccount Name” for names that don’t comply with naming conventions.
